IonDiff package#

Submodules#

IonDiff.analyze_correlations module#

class IonDiff.analyze_correlations.database(args)[source]#

Bases: object

Python Class for loading information from VASP simulations and analyzing correlations among diffusive paths.

fontsize#

Font size for plot labels and ticks.

Type:

int

dpi#

Dots per inch for saving plots.

Type:

int

__init__(self, args)[source]#

Initializes the Database class.

exp_function(x, A, B, C)[source]#

Defines a decreasing and always positive exponential function.

Parameters:

  • x (numpy.ndarray) – Input array.

  • A (float) – Exponential parameter.

  • B (float) – Exponential parameter.

  • C (float) – Exponential parameter.

Returns:

Exponential function values for the given input.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

parallel_calculation(element, args)[source]#

Auxiliar function to parallelize calculations. Obtains the distribution and compares it with a random distribution.

Parameters:

  • element (str) – Path to the simulation, material, and temperature.

  • args – Command line arguments.

Returns:

Tuple containing correlation_cumulative, temperature_cumulative, and family_cumulative.

Return type:

tuple

IonDiff.analyze_descriptors module#

class IonDiff.analyze_descriptors.descriptors(args)[source]#

Bases: object

Python Class for loading information from VASP simulations

and analyzing correlations among descriptors of diffusive paths.

__init__(self, args)[source]#

Initializes the Descriptors class.

duration_of_diffusion()[source]#

Calculates an array with the number of steps of diffusion of a particle. Expanded hoppings in ‘separate’ format is mandatory. We seek the first one for each particle and append it to the list (indexes are in agreement with ‘key’). Calculate Duration of Diffusion

Parameters:

expanded_hoppings (numpy.ndarray) – Expanded hopping data.

Returns:

Array with the duration of diffusion for each particle.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

get_cartesian_coordinates()[source]#

Returns the cartesian coordinates of a simulation from these in direct form, and the number of configurations.

Returns:

The cartesian coordinates.

Return type:

array

get_expanded_coordinates(outer=None)[source]#

Expands coordinates (time x particle). ‘Key’ stands for the index of the corresponding particle. Treats every diffusive event as from different particles. Non-diffusive particles are not considered. Expand Coordinates

Parameters:

outer (optional) – Outer value for expansion (default is None).

Returns:

A tuple containing expanded coordinates, keys, start times, end times, number of configurations, and number of particles.

Return type:

tuple

length_of_diffusion(outer='nan')[source]#

Calculates an array with the diffusion length of a particle. Coordinates must be supplied multiplied by the hoppings mask and with NaNs. We expand the coordinates (only one diffusion per column/particle). Returns the distance between initial and ending points. Periodic boundary conditions are considered. Calculate Length of Diffusion

Parameters:

outer (str, optional) – Handling for NaN values (default is ‘nan’).

Returns:

Array with the length of diffusion for each particle.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

n_diffusive_events()[source]#

Returns the number of detected diffusion events from hoppings array. Count Diffusive Events

Parameters:

  • n_conf (int) – Number of configurations.

  • n_particles (int) – Number of particles.

  • concentration (list) – Particle concentration.

  • compounds (list) – Compounds.

  • hoppings (numpy.ndarray) – Hopping data.

Returns:

Number of detected diffusion events for each particle.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

residence_time(args, threshold=1)[source]#

Returns the mean time (in pico-seconds) that a particle stay in meta-stable positions. The centers of vibration are extracted with IonDiff functions, which are compared with POSCAR positions. Diffusion events are considered as part of residence time when it happens (we do not discard those points).

Parameters:

  • MD_path (str) – Path to current simulation.

  • reference_path (str) – Path stoichiometric simulation.

  • threshold (float) – Minimum distance threshold between centers of vibration and stoichiometric positions to be considered as meta-stable positions.

Returns:

Proportion of mesta-stable positions

Return type:

residence_time (float)

time_until_diffusion(index=0, outer=None)[source]#

Calculates an array with the number of steps until the start of the first diffusion of a particle. Expanded matrix in ‘separate’ or ‘cleaned’ format is mandatory. We seek the first one for each particle and append it to the list (indexes are in agreement with ‘key’). Index = {0, -1} variable allows obtaining the first or last diffusive position of a diffusion track. Calculate Time Until Diffusion

Parameters:

  • expanded_hoppings (numpy.ndarray) – Expanded matrix of diffusive/non-diffusive processes.

  • index (int, optional) – Index to obtain the first or last diffusive position (default is 0).

  • outer (optional) – Value for handling NaN values (default is None).

Returns:

Array with time until diffusion for each particle.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

IonDiff.common_library module#

IonDiff.common_library.D_function(beta, x)[source]#
IonDiff.common_library.calculate_clusters(coordinates, n_clusters, method, distance_thd)[source]#

Calculates clusters and related information based on the chosen method and number of clusters.

Parameters:

  • coordinates (numpy.ndarray) – Input array of coordinates.

  • n_clusters (int) – Number of clusters.

  • method (str) – Clustering method (‘K-means’ or ‘Spectral’).

  • distance_thd (float) – Distance threshold for identifying vibrations.

Returns:

Tuple containing centers, classification, vibration, and cluster_change.

Return type:

tuple

IonDiff.common_library.calculate_silhouette(coordinates, method, n_attempts, silhouette_thd)[source]#

Calculates silhouette scores for different numbers of clusters and selects the optimal number.

Parameters:

  • coordinates (numpy.ndarray) – Input array of coordinates.

  • method (str) – Clustering method (‘K-means’ or ‘Spectral’).

  • n_attempts (int) – Number of attempts for clustering.

  • silhouette_thd (float) – Silhouette score threshold for selecting the number of clusters.

Returns:

Optimal number of clusters.

Return type:

int

IonDiff.common_library.find_groups(array)[source]#

Gives the ranges where an array does not have NaN values.

Parameters:

array (numpy.ndarray) – Input array.

Returns:

Array containing start and end indices of non-NaN regions.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

Example

Find non-NaN regions in an array.

Usage:

find_groups(np.array([1, 2, np.NaN, 4, 5, np.NaN, 7]))

Note

The function is useful for identifying continuous regions without NaN values.

IonDiff.common_library.get_correlation_matrix(expanded_hoppings, correlation_method='pearson', gaussian_smoothing=True, sigma=None)[source]#

Returns the correlation matrix. Gaussian smoothing is allowed. If sigma is None, it is calculated as sigma = delta T / 2.355 (FWHM).

Parameters:

  • expanded_hoppings (numpy.ndarray) – Expanded hopping matrix.

  • correlation_method (str, optional) – Correlation method. Defaults to ‘pearson’.

  • gaussian_smoothing (bool, optional) – Enable Gaussian smoothing. Defaults to True.

  • sigma (float, optional) – Standard deviation for Gaussian smoothing. Defaults to None.

Returns:

Tuple containing matrix (pandas.DataFrame) and correlation_matrix (numpy.ndarray).

Return type:

tuple

Example

Calculate the correlation matrix from expanded hopping data.

Usage:

get_correlation_matrix(np.array([[1, 0, 1], [0, 1, 1]]), correlation_method=’spearman’)

Note

The function allows customization of correlation calculations and Gaussian smoothing.

IonDiff.common_library.get_expanded_hoppings(n_conf, n_particles, concentration, particle_type, hoppings, method='original')[source]#

Expands the compressed information of hoppings into a matrix of (time x particle). ‘Key’ stands for the index of the corresponding particle.

Separate: treats every diffusive event as from different particles. Non-diffusive particles are not considered. Cleaned: non-diffusive particles are not considered. Original: just expanded as the coordinates matrix.

Parameters:

  • n_conf (int) – Number of configurations.

  • n_particles (int) – Number of particles.

  • concentration (numpy.ndarray) – Array of particle concentrations.

  • particle_type (list) – List of particle types.

  • hoppings (numpy.ndarray) – Array of hoppings.

  • method (str, optional) – Expansion method. Defaults to ‘original’.

Returns:

Tuple containing key (numpy.ndarray) and expanded_hoppings (numpy.ndarray).

Return type:

tuple

Example

Expand compressed hopping information into a matrix.

Usage:

get_expanded_hoppings(100, 3, np.array([2, 1]), [‘A’, ‘B’, ‘C’], np.array([[1, 0, 1], [0, 1, 1]]))

Note

The function provides flexibility in expanding hopping information based on different methods.

IonDiff.common_library.get_separated_groups(matrix, outer=nan)[source]#

These regions with non-NaNs are found and split. The original value is put in the corresponding place.

Parameters:

  • matrix (numpy.ndarray) – Input matrix.

  • outer (optional) – Value to use for outer regions. Defaults to np.NaN.

Returns:

Tuple containing key (numpy.ndarray) and separated_matrix (numpy.ndarray).

Return type:

tuple

Example

Separate regions with non-NaNs in a matrix.

Usage:

get_separated_groups(np.array([[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6], [7, np.NaN, 9]]))

Note

The function is useful for splitting regions with non-NaN values in a matrix.

IonDiff.common_library.information_from_VASPfile(path_to_VASPfile, file='POSCAR')[source]#

Returns cell, composition, concentration, and positions of particles from a VASP file.

Parameters:

  • path_to_VASPfile (str) – The path to the directory containing the VASP file.

  • file (str, optional) – The VASP file type, ‘POSCAR’ or ‘XDATCAR’. Default to POSCAR file.

Returns:

The lattice cell matrix. composition (list): A list of chemical composition in the form of elements. concentration (ndarray): A list of concentrations corresponding to the elements. positions (ndarray): An array of atomic positions.

Return type:

cell (ndarray)

IonDiff.common_library.load_data(path_to_simulation)[source]#

Returns all needed data in a suitable shape from a simulation.

Parameters:

path_to_simulation (str) – Path to the simulation directory.

Returns:

Tuple containing coordinates (numpy.ndarray), hoppings (numpy.ndarray), cell (numpy.ndarray), compounds (list), and concentration (numpy.ndarray).

Return type:

tuple

Example

Load simulation data from a directory.

Usage:

load_data(‘/path/to/simulation’)

Note

The function requires the existence of specific files such as ‘DIFFUSION’ and ‘XDATCAR’.

IonDiff.common_library.obtain_diffusive_family(element)[source]#

Returns the family of an element using the obtain_diffusive_information function.

Parameters:

element (str) – Element symbol.

Returns:

Diffusive family of the element.

Return type:

str

Example

Obtain the diffusive family of a given element.

Usage:

obtain_diffusive_family(‘Li’)

Note

The function automatically detects components from upper cases and numbers.

IonDiff.common_library.obtain_diffusive_information(composition, concentration, DiffTypeName=None)[source]#

Gets the diffusive and non-diffusive elements.

Parameters:

  • composition (list) – List of element symbols in the compound.

  • concentration (list) – List of element concentrations.

  • DiffTypeName (list, optional) – List of diffusive element symbols. Defaults to None.

Returns:

Tuple containing DiffTypeName (list), NonDiffTypeName (list), and diffusion_information (list).

Return type:

tuple

Example

Obtain the diffusive information from a given composition and concentration.

Usage:

obtain_diffusive_information([‘Li’, ‘O’], [1, 2])

Note

If DiffTypeName is not provided, the function automatically selects diffusive elements based on an implicit order of preference.

IonDiff.common_library.read_INCAR(path_to_simulation)[source]#

Reads VASP INCAR files. It is always expected to find these parameters.

Parameters:

path_to_simulation (str) – Path to the simulation directory.

Returns:

Tuple containing delta_t (float) and n_steps (float).

Return type:

tuple

Example

Read INCAR file from a simulation directory.

Usage:

read_INCAR(‘/path/to/simulation’)

Note

The function expects the presence of specific parameters (POTIM, NBLOCK) in the INCAR file.

IonDiff.common_library.read_XDATCAR(path_to_simulation)[source]#

Reads cell data and coordinates in direct units.

Parameters:

path_to_simulation (str) – Path to the simulation directory.

Returns:

Tuple containing cell (numpy.ndarray), n_ions (int), compounds (list), concentration (numpy.ndarray), and coordinates (numpy.ndarray).

Return type:

tuple

Example

Read XDATCAR file from a simulation directory.

Usage:

read_XDATCAR(‘/path/to/simulation’)

Note

The function expects a specific format in the XDATCAR file.

IonDiff.common_library.spectral_kwargs = {'affinity': 'nearest_neighbors', 'assign_labels': 'cluster_qr', 'n_neighbors': 1000, 'random_state': 0}#

Set of common functions for many libraries, with a general purpose.

IonDiff.common_library.weighted_regression(x, y, function, xerr=None, yerr=None, beta0=[1, 1e-05])[source]#

Performs a weighted regression using the Orthogonal Distance Regression (ODR) method.

Parameters:

  • x (numpy.ndarray) – Independent variable data.

  • y (numpy.ndarray) – Dependent variable data.

  • function (callable) – The model function to fit, with parameters and independent variable as inputs.

  • xerr (numpy.ndarray) – Standard errors of the independent variable. Defaults to None.

  • yerr (numpy.ndarray) – Standard errors of the dependent variable. Defaults to None.

  • beta0 (list, optional) – Initial guess for the model parameters. Defaults to [1, 1e-5].

Returns:

The result of the ODR fitting process, containing parameter estimates and statistics.

Return type:

odr.Output

IonDiff.identify_diffusion module#

class IonDiff.identify_diffusion.xdatcar(args)[source]#

Bases: object

Python Class for loading information from VASP simulations and identifying diffusions.

Type:

get_diffusion(args)[source]#

Obtains diffusion information from the simulation data.

Parameters:

args – Command line arguments.

Returns:

List of diffusion events, each represented as [particle index, start step, end step].

Return type:

list

get_diffusion_coefficient(args, initial_ratio=0.4, ending_ratio=1, contributions='full', n_delta_t=None, axis=None)[source]#

Calculates the diffusion coefficient from atomic trajectories using Mean Square Displacement (MSD) method.

Parameters:

  • args – Arguments containing parameters like diffusion_particle and make_plot.

  • initial_ratio (float, optional) – Ratio of the initial point for fitting the MSD curve. Defaults to 0.4.

  • ending_ratio (float, optional) – Ratio of the ending point for fitting the MSD curve. Defaults to -1.

  • contributions (str, optional) – Specifies which contributions to consider (‘full’, ‘self’, ‘distinct’). Defaults to ‘full’.

  • n_delta_t (int, optional) – Number of time steps to consider. If None, uses the entire simulation. Defaults to None.

  • axis (int, optional) – Axis along which to compute the ionic diffusion coefficient. Default to average

read_simulation(args)[source]#

Reads VASP XDATCAR files.
